elements.content: One of the benefits found in crystal engineering to build molecular materials is the possibility of understanding and thus finely controlling their photochromic performance in the solid state. We have discovered potential hints in this direction through the use of the photochromic ligand 1,2-bis­(5-carboxy-2-methylthien-3-yl)­cyclopentene, H2L, in reactions with either of two different Cu­(II) salts for the formation of two new solvatomorphs of a coordination polymer, [Cu­(L)­(py)3]·2py (1a) and [Cu­(L)­(py)3]­·2H2O­·0.5Et2O (1b). H2L is a diarylethene ligand that exhibits reversible photocyclization, allowing to reversibly modify the molecular structure and properties of coordination compounds incorporating such moiety. While the backbone of both compounds is the same, their supramolecular organization significantly differs, leading to different photochromic properties, in particular regarding the reversibility of their photoswitching processes. These remarkable structure/property relations have been assessed by optical reflectivity and Raman measurements, in light of the respective crystallographic structures.
elements.clean_text: One of the benefits found in crystal engineering to build molecular materials is the possibility of understanding and thus finely controlling their photochromic performance in the solid state. We have discovered potential hints in this direction through the use of the photochromic ligand 1,2-bis(5-carboxy-2-methylthien-3-yl)cyclopentene, H2L, in reactions with either of two different Cu(II) salts for the formation of two new solvatomorphs of a coordination polymer, [Cu(L)(py)3]⋅2py (1a) and [Cu(L)(py)3]⋅2H2O⋅0.5Et2O (1b). H2L is a diarylethene ligand that exhibits reversible photocyclization, allowing to reversibly modify the molecular structure and properties of coordination compounds incorporating such moiety. While the backbone of both compounds is the same, their supramolecular organization significantly differs, leading to different photochromic properties, in particular regarding the reversibility of their photoswitching processes. These remarkable structure/property relations have been assessed by optical reflectivity and Raman measurements, in light of the respective crystallographic structures.

elements.content: Two solvatomorphs of a Cu­(II) coordination polymer of a diarylethene light responsive ligand exhibit significantly different crystal lattice arrangements, which lead to very distinct photochromic responses. This has given the opportunity to unveil structure/property relationships, very rare in these kinds of functional materials.
elements.clean_text: Two solvatomorphs of a Cu(II) coordination polymer of a diarylethene light responsive ligand exhibit significantly different crystal lattice arrangements, which lead to very distinct photochromic responses. This has given the opportunity to unveil structure/property relationships, very rare in these kinds of functional materials.

elements.content: Molecular structures assembled by organic photochromic systems may be excellent candidates as main components of molecular photoswitching devices and biomaterials. Reversible photoisomerization processes lead to changes in physicochemical properties such as absorption spectra, magnetic behavior, electron conductivity, fluorescence, or crystal morphology, to mention only a few. Among the photochromic molecules, diarylethene-based systems are some of the most promising compounds. In addition to their chemical and structural versatility, they undergo reversible photocyclization processes with high thermal stability and quantum yield as well as with an excellent resistance to fatigue (). One of the compulsory conditions for the formation of the C–C bond in this process is that the aryl rings must be in the antiparallel conformation, in order to avoid the steric hindrance between their methyl groups upon the ring closure. It has been now established that this photoisomerization can take place either in solution or in the solid state. The complexity generally associated with solid state photochemistry has attracted attention recently. Unlike in solution, molecules within a lattice are interconnected and kept in fixed positions; therefore, their photoconverting properties could be easily influenced by small changes to the intermolecular interactions and the crystal packing. Regarding metal complexes based on diarylethene ligands, although most of the work has been devoted to organometallic multifunctional materials combining the photo- and electrochromic properties, a few reports related to photomagnetism are also available. However, little attention has been paid to crystal engineering of photoactive coordination systems, in other words to study the crystal packing requirements to perform the photoisomerization in the solid state. Along this line, some studies report on the photochromism of metal complexes in the crystalline phase, while no examples are found assessing differences in photoactivity behavior between two polymorphic compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Molecular structures assembled by organic photochromic systems may be excellent candidates as main components of molecular photoswitching devices and biomaterials. Reversible photoisomerization processes lead to changes in physicochemical properties such as absorption spectra, magnetic behavior, electron conductivity, fluorescence, or crystal morphology, to mention only a few. Among the photochromic molecules, diarylethene-based systems are some of the most promising compounds. In addition to their chemical and structural versatility, they undergo reversible photocyclization processes with high thermal stability and quantum yield as well as with an excellent resistance to fatigue (). One of the compulsory conditions for the formation of the C-C bond in this process is that the aryl rings must be in the antiparallel conformation, in order to avoid the steric hindrance between their methyl groups upon the ring closure. It has been now established that this photoisomerization can take place either in solution or in the solid state. The complexity generally associated with solid state photochemistry has attracted attention recently. Unlike in solution, molecules within a lattice are interconnected and kept in fixed positions; therefore, their photoconverting properties could be easily influenced by small changes to the intermolecular interactions and the crystal packing. Regarding metal complexes based on diarylethene ligands, although most of the work has been devoted to organometallic multifunctional materials combining the photo- and electrochromic properties, a few reports related to photomagnetism are also available. However, little attention has been paid to crystal engineering of photoactive coordination systems, in other words to study the crystal packing requirements to perform the photoisomerization in the solid state. Along this line, some studies report on the photochromism of metal complexes in the crystalline phase, while no examples are found assessing differences in photoactivity behavior between two polymorphic compounds.

elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of H  2  L and Its Reversible Photocyclization with λUV < 400 nm and λVis > 450 nm

elements.content: Despite the widespread research on diarylethene derivates, these materials are indeed, mainly based on the diarylperfluoropentene entity. The synthesis of these compounds is neither trivial nor easy to scale up since they use octafluorocyclopentene as reagent, which is very volatile and expensive while the yields are very low. To solve these problems, Feringa et al. reported a new synthetic pathway where a perhydro-cyclopentene unit is used instead of the perfluoro analogue. Interestingly, although this procedure is cheaper and allows large scale reactions, only a few coordination complexes based on these derivatives can be found in the literature.
elements.clean_text: Despite the widespread research on diarylethene derivates, these materials are indeed, mainly based on the diarylperfluoropentene entity. The synthesis of these compounds is neither trivial nor easy to scale up since they use octafluorocyclopentene as reagent, which is very volatile and expensive while the yields are very low. To solve these problems, Feringa et al. reported a new synthetic pathway where a perhydro-cyclopentene unit is used instead of the perfluoro analogue. Interestingly, although this procedure is cheaper and allows large scale reactions, only a few coordination complexes based on these derivatives can be found in the literature.

elements.content: We report here two solvatomorphs of a Cu­(II) coordination polymer, [Cu­(L)­(py)3] (1), where H 2 L is the fluorine-free photochromic ligand 1,2-(5-carboxy-2-methyl-thiophen-3-yl)-cyclopentene (). Both compounds feature polymeric chains alternating pyridine bound Cu­(II) ions and L2– ligands acting as bridging units through their carboxylate functionalities. The crystal packing of these chains is quite different due to the presence of dissimilar guest molecules. As a consequence, although both solvatomorphs are photoactive, the kinetics of the process is drastically different. The reversible photoconversion in the crystalline phase for both complexes has been characterized by means of optical reflectivity and Raman spectroscopy techniques. Moreover, the magnetic properties of both compounds have also been assessed. The distinct behaviors are rationalized in light of the structural information.
elements.clean_text: We report here two solvatomorphs of a Cu(II) coordination polymer, [Cu(L)(py)3] (1), where H  2  L is the fluorine-free photochromic ligand 1,2-(5-carboxy-2-methyl-thiophen-3-yl)-cyclopentene (). Both compounds feature polymeric chains alternating pyridine bound Cu(II) ions and L2- ligands acting as bridging units through their carboxylate functionalities. The crystal packing of these chains is quite different due to the presence of dissimilar guest molecules. As a consequence, although both solvatomorphs are photoactive, the kinetics of the process is drastically different. The reversible photoconversion in the crystalline phase for both complexes has been characterized by means of optical reflectivity and Raman spectroscopy techniques. Moreover, the magnetic properties of both compounds have also been assessed. The distinct behaviors are rationalized in light of the structural information.

elements.content: Compounds 1a and 1b are solvatomorphs of the same coordination polymer. The composition of their crystal lattice is [Cu­(L)­(py)3]·2py (1a) and [Cu­(L)­(py)3]­·2H2O­·0.5Et2O (1b), respectively, thus just differing in the nature of the solvent molecules of crystallization. While both reactions were performed through the exact same procedure and using the same solvents, the only distinction was the initial source of Cu­(II) metal ions: Cu­(AcO)2·H2O and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O for 1a and 1b, respectively. Interestingly, however, the different counterions are not present in the final products. Therefore, the reasons for a different final composition and solid state arrangement (see below) may have to do with the role that AcO– and NO3 – play on the equilibria taking place in solution, or with the larger amount of water borne by the nitrate salt. Both procedures were found to be fully reproducible.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Molecular Structures

Compounds 1a and 1b are solvatomorphs of the same coordination polymer. The composition of their crystal lattice is [Cu(L)(py)3]⋅2py (1a) and [Cu(L)(py)3]⋅2H2O⋅0.5Et2O (1b), respectively, thus just differing in the nature of the solvent molecules of crystallization. While both reactions were performed through the exact same procedure and using the same solvents, the only distinction was the initial source of Cu(II) metal ions: Cu(AcO)2⋅H2O and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O for 1a and 1b, respectively. Interestingly, however, the different counterions are not present in the final products. Therefore, the reasons for a different final composition and solid state arrangement (see below) may have to do with the role that AcO- and NO3 - play on the equilibria taking place in solution, or with the larger amount of water borne by the nitrate salt. Both procedures were found to be fully reproducible.

elements.content: Compounds 1a and 1b crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/c (Table S1). Their asymmetric unit (Figure S1) coincides with their empirical formulas, and the unit cell contains four such units. Selected metric parameters are listed in Tables S2 and S3. Both compounds consist of polymeric chains of Cu­(II) ions linked by the L2– ligands through their end carboxylate groups acting as monodentate donors on each Cu site ( and S2). Thus, the unique Cu site exhibits two trans Cu–O bonds (distances: 1.954(2) and 1.973(2) Å, 1a; 1.950(3) and 1.954(3) Å, 1b). The Cu···O distances to the other oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups diverge more for complex 1a (2.768 and 3.322(3) Å) than for 1b (2.982(4) and 3.023(4) Å). Additionally, each metal ion is coordinated by three solvent pyridine molecules in a mer fashion. The Cu­(II) ions are thus described as five coordinate (N3O2) with slightly distorted square pyramidal geometries (Addison parameters τ of 0.18 and 0.27 for 1a and 1b, respectively). In 1a, the axial site is occupied by a pyridine molecule that exhibits occupational disorder over two positions (0.73:0.27 ratio). In 1b, the axial pyridine group is fully ordered. In both compounds, the coordination polyhedron around Cu­(II) alternates within the chain between two approximately opposite orientations; thus the torsion angles between adjacent Cu–Naxial bonds within the polymers are 150.56(4)° and 119.58(4)° for 1a and 1b, respectively. The cyclopentene unit of the photochromic spacer alternates as well between two almost opposite orientations (Figure S2). In both cases, the chains are not chiral, since both enantiomeric conformers of the L 2– ligand are present and alternate within the chains.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1a and 1b crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/c (Table S1). Their asymmetric unit (Figure S1) coincides with their empirical formulas, and the unit cell contains four such units. Selected metric parameters are listed in Tables S2 and S3. Both compounds consist of polymeric chains of Cu(II) ions linked by the L2- ligands through their end carboxylate groups acting as monodentate donors on each Cu site ( and S2). Thus, the unique Cu site exhibits two trans Cu-O bonds (distances: 1.954(2) and 1.973(2) Å, 1a; 1.950(3) and 1.954(3) Å, 1b). The Cu⋅⋅⋅O distances to the other oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups diverge more for complex 1a (2.768 and 3.322(3) Å) than for 1b (2.982(4) and 3.023(4) Å). Additionally, each metal ion is coordinated by three solvent pyridine molecules in a mer fashion. The Cu(II) ions are thus described as five coordinate (N3O2) with slightly distorted square pyramidal geometries (Addison parameters τ of 0.18 and 0.27 for 1a and 1b, respectively). In 1a, the axial site is occupied by a pyridine molecule that exhibits occupational disorder over two positions (0.73:0.27 ratio). In 1b, the axial pyridine group is fully ordered. In both compounds, the coordination polyhedron around Cu(II) alternates within the chain between two approximately opposite orientations; thus the torsion angles between adjacent Cu-Naxial bonds within the polymers are 150.56(4)° and 119.58(4)° for 1a and 1b, respectively. The cyclopentene unit of the photochromic spacer alternates as well between two almost opposite orientations (Figure S2). In both cases, the chains are not chiral, since both enantiomeric conformers of the L  2- ligand are present and alternate within the chains.

elements.content: Representation of the polymeric chain of 1a with heteroatoms of the asymmetric unit (and some symmetry equivalent) labeled. The polymeric chain of 1b is very similar (see Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of the polymeric chain of 1a with heteroatoms of the asymmetric unit (and some symmetry equivalent) labeled. The polymeric chain of 1b is very similar (see Figure S2).

elements.content: The crystal packing of compound 1a shows a two-dimensional arrangement of the chains linked by π–π stacking interactions between the equatorial pyridine molecules (intercentroid distance of 3.586(1) Å; Figure S3). Within the sheets, the interchain neighboring Cu centers exhibit the exact same mutual orientation, as do adjacent diarylethene units. The free space available between chains is shaped as infinite channels efficiently occupied by one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular arrays of pyridine molecules connected by a combination of π–π stacking and C–H···π interactions ( and S4). The chains of 1b also organize as two-dimensional (2D) assemblies ( and S5) through lateral π–π stacking interactions involving equatorial pyridine ligands (intercentroid distance of 3.663(1) Å, Figure S5). Here, however, adjacent Cu­(II) ions between chains exhibit opposite orientations, as do adjacent diarylethene units. This arrangement conduces to 2D sheets that are much more corrugated than in 1a and also prevents the establishment of 1D channels as seen in the other compound. Instead, two types of cavities are formed in between the sheets ( and S6): (i) one with a hydrophobic character that contains one-half disordered molecule of ether and (ii) one hydrophilic that sees four noncoordinated carboxylate O atoms pointing toward its interior forming a total of six hydrogen bonds with four hosted water molecules (Figure S7). This network of hydrogen bonds contributes to the cementing of the 2D sheets of 1b within the tridimensional lattice. In both compounds, the thiophenyl rings within the photoswitchable unit exhibit an antiparallel arrangement, a necessary condition for the photochromic conversion to proceed. Another important parameter in this respect is the distance between the C atoms that form a new bond during the cyclization process, which needs to be shorter than approximately 4 Å. This distance is 3.550(7) Å and 3.479(10) for 1a (C5···C13) and 1b (C20···C30), respectively. This important parameter, very similar in both compounds, is not only correlated with the torsion angle about the ethylene central unit (4.21° and 4.88°). There is also a role played by the mutual rotation of the thiophene units via the C–C bond connecting them to the central cyclopentene (angles between thiophenes of 58.20° and 58.16°, respectively).
elements.clean_text: The crystal packing of compound 1a shows a two-dimensional arrangement of the chains linked by π-π stacking interactions between the equatorial pyridine molecules (intercentroid distance of 3.586(1) Å; Figure S3). Within the sheets, the interchain neighboring Cu centers exhibit the exact same mutual orientation, as do adjacent diarylethene units. The free space available between chains is shaped as infinite channels efficiently occupied by one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular arrays of pyridine molecules connected by a combination of π-π stacking and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions ( and S4). The chains of 1b also organize as two-dimensional (2D) assemblies ( and S5) through lateral π-π stacking interactions involving equatorial pyridine ligands (intercentroid distance of 3.663(1) Å, Figure S5). Here, however, adjacent Cu(II) ions between chains exhibit opposite orientations, as do adjacent diarylethene units. This arrangement conduces to 2D sheets that are much more corrugated than in 1a and also prevents the establishment of 1D channels as seen in the other compound. Instead, two types of cavities are formed in between the sheets ( and S6): (i) one with a hydrophobic character that contains one-half disordered molecule of ether and (ii) one hydrophilic that sees four noncoordinated carboxylate O atoms pointing toward its interior forming a total of six hydrogen bonds with four hosted water molecules (Figure S7). This network of hydrogen bonds contributes to the cementing of the 2D sheets of 1b within the tridimensional lattice. In both compounds, the thiophenyl rings within the photoswitchable unit exhibit an antiparallel arrangement, a necessary condition for the photochromic conversion to proceed. Another important parameter in this respect is the distance between the C atoms that form a new bond during the cyclization process, which needs to be shorter than approximately 4 Å. This distance is 3.550(7) Å and 3.479(10) for 1a (C5⋅⋅⋅C13) and 1b (C20⋅⋅⋅C30), respectively. This important parameter, very similar in both compounds, is not only correlated with the torsion angle about the ethylene central unit (4.21° and 4.88°). There is also a role played by the mutual rotation of the thiophene units via the C-C bond connecting them to the central cyclopentene (angles between thiophenes of 58.20° and 58.16°, respectively).

elements.content: Representation of two stacks of polymeric chains of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom), forming two adjacent sheets and emphasizing the 1D channels (1a) or succession of cavities (1b) parallel to a traversing both lattices. The channels are occupied by ordered molecules of pyridine molecules (1a, shown light green) and the cavities (1b) by disordered ether (light blue) or water (red balls). The color code of the polymer is as in Figure .
elements.clean_text: 2  Representation of two stacks of polymeric chains of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom), forming two adjacent sheets and emphasizing the 1D channels (1a) or succession of cavities (1b) parallel to a traversing both lattices. The channels are occupied by ordered molecules of pyridine molecules (1a, shown light green) and the cavities (1b) by disordered ether (light blue) or water (red balls). The color code of the polymer is as in Figure  .

elements.content: The photoisomerization properties of compounds 1a and 1b in the solid state were examined through optical reflectivity and Raman spectroscopic measurements. The reason why these two techniques were chosen is that these are ideal for unveiling effects near the surface of solids. All attempts to reveal the effects of phototransformation to the bulk of the sample (single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction or magnetochemistry) failed. However, the system has been amenable to surface studies, as shown below.
elements.clean_text:
Photoswitching Properties

The photoisomerization properties of compounds 1a and 1b in the solid state were examined through optical reflectivity and Raman spectroscopic measurements. The reason why these two techniques were chosen is that these are ideal for unveiling effects near the surface of solids. All attempts to reveal the effects of phototransformation to the bulk of the sample (single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction or magnetochemistry) failed. However, the system has been amenable to surface studies, as shown below.

elements.content: The photoswitching properties of H 2 L, 1a, and 1b were investigated by optical reflectivity in the solid state (in the 400–900 nm range). As a preliminary experiment, the variable temperature optical reflectivity of the H 2 L ligand in its opened form was determined (Figure S8), which showed almost no spectral variations with temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Reflectivity Measurements

The photoswitching properties of H  2  L, 1a, and 1b were investigated by optical reflectivity in the solid state (in the 400-900 nm range). As a preliminary experiment, the variable temperature optical reflectivity of the H  2  L ligand in its opened form was determined (Figure S8), which showed almost no spectral variations with temperature.

elements.content: When a powdered sample of H 2 L was irradiated continuously with UV light (365 nm) at 290 K, the pale brown solid of the opened form turned deep violet as expected in the presence of the closed isomer. This change of color can be followed during approximately 2 h as a clear decrease of the absolute reflectivity, most noticeable in the 450–650 nm region where a broad band appears progressively (A).
elements.clean_text: When a powdered sample of H  2  L was irradiated continuously with UV light (365 nm) at 290 K, the pale brown solid of the opened form turned deep violet as expected in the presence of the closed isomer. This change of color can be followed during approximately 2 h as a clear decrease of the absolute reflectivity, most noticeable in the 450-650 nm region where a broad band appears progressively (A).

elements.content: Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for H 2 L upon continuous irradiation at 295 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.
elements.clean_text: 3  Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for H  2  L upon continuous irradiation at 295 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.

elements.content: After 4.5 h of irradiation, practically no further evolution could be observed (C, vide infra). Then, the thermal variation of the optical reflectivity properties of the irradiated/closed product was also studied (Figure S9) and showed again almost no variation with temperature. If the compound is then irradiated with visible light (455 and 530 nm) at room temperature, the photoconversion of H 2 L is reversed partially (with 530 nm light) or totally (with 455 nm light), as followed again through absolute reflectivity (B and S10). The kinetics and reversibility of both photochromic H 2 L reactions were studied at 295 K through the time dependence of the absolute reflectivity at a specific wavelength (selected here at 500 nm), irradiating with light of 365 nm for the direct process and of 455 nm for the reverse isomerization (C). The absolute reflectivity at 500 nm rapidly decreases from 0.40 to 0.06 under 365 nm excitation, while it increases again upon excitation with 455 nm light, to reach in about 50 min the value of 0.36. To the best of our knowledge, the optical properties of H 2 L in the solid state have not been previously reported. Nevertheless, the noticeable decrease of optical reflectivity of this compound in the 450–650 nm range is consistent with previously observed changes to its solution absorption spectra upon irradiation with UV light. The latter mainly consist of the development of a broad band centered at 530 nm attributed to π···π* transitions through the conjugated skeleton. Indeed, the solution and solid state spectral behavior may not change significantly, as already observed for a molecule analogous to H 2 L, with a perfluoropentene instead of a pentene unit.
elements.clean_text: After 4.5 h of irradiation, practically no further evolution could be observed (C, vide infra). Then, the thermal variation of the optical reflectivity properties of the irradiated/closed product was also studied (Figure S9) and showed again almost no variation with temperature. If the compound is then irradiated with visible light (455 and 530 nm) at room temperature, the photoconversion of H  2  L is reversed partially (with 530 nm light) or totally (with 455 nm light), as followed again through absolute reflectivity (B and S10). The kinetics and reversibility of both photochromic H  2  L reactions were studied at 295 K through the time dependence of the absolute reflectivity at a specific wavelength (selected here at 500 nm), irradiating with light of 365 nm for the direct process and of 455 nm for the reverse isomerization (C). The absolute reflectivity at 500 nm rapidly decreases from 0.40 to 0.06 under 365 nm excitation, while it increases again upon excitation with 455 nm light, to reach in about 50 min the value of 0.36. To the best of our knowledge, the optical properties of H  2  L in the solid state have not been previously reported. Nevertheless, the noticeable decrease of optical reflectivity of this compound in the 450-650 nm range is consistent with previously observed changes to its solution absorption spectra upon irradiation with UV light. The latter mainly consist of the development of a broad band centered at 530 nm attributed to π⋅⋅⋅π* transitions through the conjugated skeleton. Indeed, the solution and solid state spectral behavior may not change significantly, as already observed for a molecule analogous to H  2  L, with a perfluoropentene instead of a pentene unit.

elements.content: The same experimental protocol was carried out for compounds 1a and 1b. First, reflectivity experiments were performed in order to determine the temperature dependence of the spectra of both complexes (Figures S11 and S12). Both 1a and 1b display strong absorptions above 700 nm due to the d–d transitions centered on the Cu2+ ions. Besides, more pronounced thermal changes than observed for H 2 L (Figures S8 and S9) were detected, reflecting on a larger temperature influence of the near-infrared transitions, more enhanced for 1b (Figures S11 and S12). These thermal variations are fully reversible. For complex 1a, irradiation with UV light (λ = 365 nm) causes a decrease of the reflectivity that is most obvious in the 450–600 nm range (A), which may be attributed to the formation of the closed form isomer. A steady state was reached after approximately 90 min of irradiation. The thermal variation of the reflectivity properties of the irradiated/closed form were also examined (Figure S12), and similarly to the open form, the variations were fully reversible. Subsequently, the reverse photoconversion to the original opened form was investigated with different wavelengths: λ = 625, 590, 530, and 455 nm (Figure S14). Only the green light (λ = 530 nm) was active to reverse the photoisomerisation process (B). Actually, time dependence studies of the absolute reflectivity during the excitation–de-excitation cycle reveal that the reversibility is only partial as the initial absolute reflectivity is not fully recovered (C). It is conceivable that the first isomerization causes changes to the crystal lattice that prevent the restoration of the exact original system. Quite remarkably, complex 1b shows a totally different behavior. First, it requires 5-fold longer UV irradiation times (approximately 8 h) than 1a to reach a photostationary state, presumably corresponding to the closed form (A). Second, the associated reverse process was not observed (B). Note that several attempts with other wavelengths in the visible range did not lead to reversibility for 1b. The failure to cause any reverse conversion may be attributed to changes of the crystal structure after the closure of the diarylethene, blocking the reverse process. The resulting system also exhibits a thermal dependence of the absolute reflectivity (Figure S15) similar to that of the original sample. The different optical and photoconversion properties for both coordination polymers must be rooted on their crystalline arrangement. One difference is that the layers made of chains in 1b are packed through a network of H-bonding interactions (mediated by water molecules) that is absent in 1a. This may render the molecular rearrangement and the lattice more rigid and thus more difficult to adapt to the photocyclization for 1b than for 1a. It is possible that the parallel disposition of adjacent chains in 1a (vide supra, Figure S3) is preserved in both of its forms. The dramatic difference between the photoactivity kinetics of the two compounds suggests that the alternating arrangement in 1b does not facilitate the concerted atomic movement throughout the lattice required for the reversible photoconversion.
elements.clean_text: The same experimental protocol was carried out for compounds 1a and 1b. First, reflectivity experiments were performed in order to determine the temperature dependence of the spectra of both complexes (Figures S11 and S12). Both 1a and 1b display strong absorptions above 700 nm due to the d-d transitions centered on the Cu2+ ions. Besides, more pronounced thermal changes than observed for H  2  L (Figures S8 and S9) were detected, reflecting on a larger temperature influence of the near-infrared transitions, more enhanced for 1b (Figures S11 and S12). These thermal variations are fully reversible. For complex 1a, irradiation with UV light (λ = 365 nm) causes a decrease of the reflectivity that is most obvious in the 450-600 nm range (A), which may be attributed to the formation of the closed form isomer. A steady state was reached after approximately 90 min of irradiation. The thermal variation of the reflectivity properties of the irradiated/closed form were also examined (Figure S12), and similarly to the open form, the variations were fully reversible. Subsequently, the reverse photoconversion to the original opened form was investigated with different wavelengths: λ = 625, 590, 530, and 455 nm (Figure S14). Only the green light (λ = 530 nm) was active to reverse the photoisomerisation process (B). Actually, time dependence studies of the absolute reflectivity during the excitation-de-excitation cycle reveal that the reversibility is only partial as the initial absolute reflectivity is not fully recovered (C). It is conceivable that the first isomerization causes changes to the crystal lattice that prevent the restoration of the exact original system. Quite remarkably, complex 1b shows a totally different behavior. First, it requires 5-fold longer UV irradiation times (approximately 8 h) than 1a to reach a photostationary state, presumably corresponding to the closed form (A). Second, the associated reverse process was not observed (B). Note that several attempts with other wavelengths in the visible range did not lead to reversibility for 1b. The failure to cause any reverse conversion may be attributed to changes of the crystal structure after the closure of the diarylethene, blocking the reverse process. The resulting system also exhibits a thermal dependence of the absolute reflectivity (Figure S15) similar to that of the original sample. The different optical and photoconversion properties for both coordination polymers must be rooted on their crystalline arrangement. One difference is that the layers made of chains in 1b are packed through a network of H-bonding interactions (mediated by water molecules) that is absent in 1a. This may render the molecular rearrangement and the lattice more rigid and thus more difficult to adapt to the photocyclization for 1b than for 1a. It is possible that the parallel disposition of adjacent chains in 1a (vide supra, Figure S3) is preserved in both of its forms. The dramatic difference between the photoactivity kinetics of the two compounds suggests that the alternating arrangement in 1b does not facilitate the concerted atomic movement throughout the lattice required for the reversible photoconversion.

(C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.

elements.content: It must be noted that, to the best of our knowledge, there are no reported studies about the role of the supramolecular arrangement on the photochromic properties of metal complexes assembled by diaryelethene ligands. However, some papers report on the quenching or the appearance of photoconversion in diarylethene single crystals depending on the exact crystal structure. For instance, an increase of the quantum yield of up to 100% can be achieved by introducing guest molecules (favoring the antiparallel arrangement of thiophenyls via intermolecular interactions) into the lattice.
elements.clean_text: It must be noted that, to the best of our knowledge, there are no reported studies about the role of the supramolecular arrangement on the photochromic properties of metal complexes assembled by diaryelethene ligands. However, some papers report on the quenching or the appearance of photoconversion in diarylethene single crystals depending on the exact crystal structure. For instance, an increase of the quantum yield of up to 100% can be achieved by introducing guest molecules (favoring the antiparallel arrangement of thiophenyls via intermolecular interactions) into the lattice.

elements.content: In order to obtain some additional insight into the possible reasons for this difference in reactivity, we performed a Hirshfeld analysis. This tool allows calculation of the surface around a given species of the lattice (here the portion of the polymer contained in one asymmetric unit) where the electron density has gradient zero. The distances to the inner and outer closest atoms to each point of the surface are compared with the sum of van der Waals (VdW) radii of these atoms and the surface adopts a color depending on this comparison, which is red, white, and blue for interactions shorter, equal, or longer than VdW contacts. A qualitative inspection of these surfaces (), specifically near the atoms that are to experience a larger displacement upon photoisomerization, suggests that compound 1a exhibits weaker VdW interactions with the surroundings (more blue than white color) than 1b (with more white areas).
elements.clean_text: In order to obtain some additional insight into the possible reasons for this difference in reactivity, we performed a Hirshfeld analysis. This tool allows calculation of the surface around a given species of the lattice (here the portion of the polymer contained in one asymmetric unit) where the electron density has gradient zero. The distances to the inner and outer closest atoms to each point of the surface are compared with the sum of van der Waals (VdW) radii of these atoms and the surface adopts a color depending on this comparison, which is red, white, and blue for interactions shorter, equal, or longer than VdW contacts. A qualitative inspection of these surfaces (), specifically near the atoms that are to experience a larger displacement upon photoisomerization, suggests that compound 1a exhibits weaker VdW interactions with the surroundings (more blue than white color) than 1b (with more white areas).

elements.content: Hirshfeld surfaces of a [Cu­(L)­(py)3] fragment of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom). The right figures are shown in the transparent mode in order to show the underlying molecular fragments. The red circles indicate the area of interest, corresponding to the atoms that displace the most upon the photisomerization. In this area, the surface is slightly more blue for compound 1a.
elements.clean_text: 6  Hirshfeld surfaces of a [Cu(L)(py)3] fragment of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom). The red circles indicate the area of interest, corresponding to the atoms that displace the most upon the photisomerization. In this area, the surface is slightly more blue for compound 1a.

elements.content: While the analysis does not produce any strong indication, the observations seem consistent with the experimental behavior of both solvatomorphs. These interactions in 1b are primarily with neighboring photochromic units, which is not the case for 1a (Figures S16 and S17).
elements.clean_text: While the analysis does not produce any strong indication, the observations seem consistent with the experimental behavior of both solvatomorphs. These interactions in 1b are primarily with neighboring photochromic units, which is not the case for 1a (Figures S16 and S17).

elements.content: The H 2 L ligand and its Cu­(II) complex 1a exhibit Raman spectra similar to that of other previously studied bisthiophenylethene derivatives ( and S18). Spectra on powdered samples of both compounds were then recorded after subsequent and repeated cycles of continuous UV light irradiation (<425 nm). During the course of this irradiation, the color of the illuminated area changes in the same way as was observed during the optical reflectivity experiments. This process, however, does not result in large spectral Raman changes. However, as seen on previous compounds, the appearance of a distinct band near 1500 cm–1 upon photoisomerization is very obvious and constitutes a marker of the ring closure. Importantly, the reversal of the process by illumination with visible light (>430 nm) takes place indeed with complete disappearance of this marker, which is consistent with the reflectivity results for H 2 L and 1a. This peak is attributed to a CC stretching vibration of the thiophene unit when it becomes embedded within the extended conjugated polyenic structure of the closed form. Regarding complex 1b, the experiments were hampered by the weakness of the signal. This is ascribed to the instability of the sample under the Raman beam excitation. This confirms once again the dramatic differences in photoresponsive behavior of both solvatomorphs.
elements.clean_text:
Raman Spectroscopy

The H  2  L ligand and its Cu(II) complex 1a exhibit Raman spectra similar to that of other previously studied bisthiophenylethene derivatives ( and S18). Spectra on powdered samples of both compounds were then recorded after subsequent and repeated cycles of continuous UV light irradiation (<425 nm). During the course of this irradiation, the color of the illuminated area changes in the same way as was observed during the optical reflectivity experiments. This process, however, does not result in large spectral Raman changes. However, as seen on previous compounds, the appearance of a distinct band near 1500 cm-1 upon photoisomerization is very obvious and constitutes a marker of the ring closure. Importantly, the reversal of the process by illumination with visible light (>430 nm) takes place indeed with complete disappearance of this marker, which is consistent with the reflectivity results for H  2  L and 1a. This peak is attributed to a CC stretching vibration of the thiophene unit when it becomes embedded within the extended conjugated polyenic structure of the closed form. Regarding complex 1b, the experiments were hampered by the weakness of the signal. This is ascribed to the instability of the sample under the Raman beam excitation. This confirms once again the dramatic differences in photoresponsive behavior of both solvatomorphs.

elements.content: Evolution of the Raman spectra (in the window of interest) of ligand H 2 L and complex 1a, respectively, upon continuous irradiation with UV-light (λ < 425 nm) (left panels) and visible light (λ > 430 nm) (right panels), showing the reversible changes occurring upon photoisomerization.
elements.clean_text: 7  Evolution of the Raman spectra (in the window of interest) of ligand H  2  L and complex 1a, respectively, upon continuous irradiation with UV-light (λ < 425 nm) (left panels) and visible light (λ > 430 nm) (right panels), showing the reversible changes occurring upon photoisomerization.

elements.content: The variable temperature bulk magnetic susceptibility of complexes 1a and 1b before and after UV light irradiation was measured on powdered microcrystalline samples under a constant magnetic field of 0.1 T. The χT vs T plots (χ is the molar paramagnetic susceptibility per Cu­(II) center; Figure S19) of compounds 1a and 1b show that in all cases (open or closed forms), the susceptibility follows a quasi-Curie law along the whole temperature range in agreement with noninteracting S = 1/2 systems (a constant value of 0.44 cm3 K mol–1 for both, 1a and 1b, before irradiation and of 0.43 cm3 K mol–1 for both complexes after the irradiation with UV light). This indicates that the diaryl ethene spacer, as expected, does not mediate any significant magnetic exchange between the metal ions. The irradiation of powdered samples of both compounds with UV light (λ = 385 nm, P = 3 mW/cm2) using the same LEDs than the ones used for the optical reflectivity measurements, causes a change of color from green to deep violet. The absence of changes to the magnetic susceptibility in the resulting samples (Figure S19) may be a consequence that upon ring closure, the diarylethene H 2 L spacer does not increase in any efficient way the Cu···Cu exchange interactions. In addition, one must also consider that the photoisomerization in the solid state may not have taken place throughout the entire bulk of the sample but only down to a certain depth below the surface.
elements.clean_text:
Bulk Magnetic Measurements

The variable temperature bulk magnetic susceptibility of complexes 1a and 1b before and after UV light irradiation was measured on powdered microcrystalline samples under a constant magnetic field of 0.1 T. The χT vs T plots (χ is the molar paramagnetic susceptibility per Cu(II) center; Figure S19) of compounds 1a and 1b show that in all cases (open or closed forms), the susceptibility follows a quasi-Curie law along the whole temperature range in agreement with noninteracting S = 1/2 systems (a constant value of 0.44 cm3 K mol-1 for both, 1a and 1b, before irradiation and of 0.43 cm3 K mol-1 for both complexes after the irradiation with UV light). This indicates that the diaryl ethene spacer, as expected, does not mediate any significant magnetic exchange between the metal ions. The irradiation of powdered samples of both compounds with UV light (λ = 385 nm, P = 3 mW/cm2) using the same LEDs than the ones used for the optical reflectivity measurements, causes a change of color from green to deep violet. The absence of changes to the magnetic susceptibility in the resulting samples (Figure S19) may be a consequence that upon ring closure, the diarylethene H  2  L spacer does not increase in any efficient way the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu exchange interactions. In addition, one must also consider that the photoisomerization in the solid state may not have taken place throughout the entire bulk of the sample but only down to a certain depth below the surface.

elements.content: The reaction of a diarylethene photochromic dicarboxylate ligand, H 2 L, with two different Cu­(II) salts produces two different solvatomorphs of the polymeric complex [Cu­(L)­(py)3] (1). These compounds do not contain any counterions introduced by the Cu salts (NO3 – or AcO–), but they certainly induce the disparity in the outcome of both reactions. The nature of the cocrystallized solvent (pyridine or H2O/Et2O) gives rise to significantly different organizations in the crystal lattice. Quite remarkably, these differences result in noticeably differing photochromic properties for these two systems. Thus, the pyridine solvate, 1a, exhibits reversible solid state ring closure photoisomerism, whereas this process is significantly hampered for the other system, 1b, and seems to be irreversible. Thus, these results show that the subtleties of crystal engineering may constitute an avenue for modulating the photoactivity in the solid state, with potential for the understanding of these intriguing functional materials and for the design of future single crystal photochromic systems.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The reaction of a diarylethene photochromic dicarboxylate ligand, H  2  L, with two different Cu(II) salts produces two different solvatomorphs of the polymeric complex [Cu(L)(py)3] (1). These compounds do not contain any counterions introduced by the Cu salts (NO3 - or AcO-), but they certainly induce the disparity in the outcome of both reactions. The nature of the cocrystallized solvent (pyridine or H2O/Et2O) gives rise to significantly different organizations in the crystal lattice. Quite remarkably, these differences result in noticeably differing photochromic properties for these two systems. Thus, the pyridine solvate, 1a, exhibits reversible solid state ring closure photoisomerism, whereas this process is significantly hampered for the other system, 1b, and seems to be irreversible. Thus, these results show that the subtleties of crystal engineering may constitute an avenue for modulating the photoactivity in the solid state, with potential for the understanding of these intriguing functional materials and for the design of future single crystal photochromic systems.

elements.content: All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligand 1,2-bis­(5-carboxy-2-methylthien-3-yl)­cyclopentene, H 2 L, was synthesized according to a previously reported procedure. All coordination chemistry reactions were performed under aerobic conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The ligand 1,2-bis(5-carboxy-2-methylthien-3-yl)cyclopentene, H  2  L, was synthesized according to a previously reported procedure. All coordination chemistry reactions were performed under aerobic conditions.

elements.content: A solution of H 2 L (50 mg, 0.143 mmol) and NaH (11.46 mg, 0.286 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL) was added to a solution of Cu­(AcO)2·H2O (28.66 mg, 0.143 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL). The resulting green solution was stirred for 2 h and filtered, and the filtrate was layered with ether (30 mL). After 1 day, blue crystals were obtained (yield 92 mg, 78%). IR (KrB pellet, cm–1): 3439 b, 3108 w, 3065 w, 2904 w, 2843 w, 1600 s, 1465 s, 1447 s, 1378 s, 1334 s, 1213 m, 1147 m, 1069m, 769 s, 695 m. Anal. (found) calcd for 1a·3H2O­(−2py): C, (55.25) 54.80; H, (4.70) 5.03; N, (5.38) 5.99.
elements.clean_text:
[Cu(L)(py)3]⋅2py (1a)

A solution of H  2  L (50 mg, 0.143 mmol) and NaH (11.46 mg, 0.286 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL) was added to a solution of Cu(AcO)2⋅H2O (28.66 mg, 0.143 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL). The resulting green solution was stirred for 2 h and filtered, and the filtrate was layered with ether (30 mL). After 1 day, blue crystals were obtained (yield 92 mg, 78%). IR (KrB pellet, cm-1): 3439 b, 3108 w, 3065 w, 2904 w, 2843 w, 1600 s, 1465 s, 1447 s, 1378 s, 1334 s, 1213 m, 1147 m, 1069m, 769 s, 695 m. Anal. (found) calcd for 1a⋅3H2O(-2py): C, (55.25) 54.80; H, (4.70) 5.03; N, (5.38) 5.99.

elements.content: A solution of H 2 L (50 mg, 0.143 mmol) and NaH (11.46 mg, 0.286 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL) was added to a solution of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (33.26 mg, 0.143 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL). The resulting green solution was mixed for 2 h and filtered, and the filtrate was layered with ether (30 mL). After 5 days, blue crystals were collected (yield 67 mg, 66%). IR (KrB pellet, cm–1): 3400 b, 2969 m, 2908 m, 2834 m, 1605 s, 1460 s, 1378 s, 1343 s, 1216 m, 1150 m, 1044 s, 875 w, 804 s, 773 s, 695 s. Anal. (found) calcd for 1b (−0.5Et2O): C, (56.60) 56.24; H, (4.75) 4.88; N, (6.15) 6.15.
elements.clean_text:
[Cu(L)(py)3]⋅2H2O⋅0.5Et2O (1b)

A solution of H  2  L (50 mg, 0.143 mmol) and NaH (11.46 mg, 0.286 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL) was added to a solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (33.26 mg, 0.143 mmol) in pyridine (15 mL). The resulting green solution was mixed for 2 h and filtered, and the filtrate was layered with ether (30 mL). After 5 days, blue crystals were collected (yield 67 mg, 66%). IR (KrB pellet, cm-1): 3400 b, 2969 m, 2908 m, 2834 m, 1605 s, 1460 s, 1378 s, 1343 s, 1216 m, 1150 m, 1044 s, 875 w, 804 s, 773 s, 695 s. Anal. (found) calcd for 1b (-0.5Et2O): C, (56.60) 56.24; H, (4.75) 4.88; N, (6.15) 6.15.

elements.content: The elemental analysis was performed with a PerkinElmer Series II CHNS/O analyzer 2400, at the Servei de Microanàlisi of CSIC, Barcelona, Spain. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellet samples on a Nicolet 5700 FTIR spectrometer. Raman spectra of microcrystalline samples were obtained using a Jobin-Yvon LabRam HR 800 spectrometer with a CCD camera cooled at −70 °C and an optical microscope Olympus BXFM. The Raman spectra of both the open and closed isomers were acquired with an excitation wavelength of 785 nm in order to avoid the cycloreversion reaction of the closed form isomer. The current employed was 185 mA with the minimum power available (10% of the total) to prevent sample damaging. Magnetic measurements were performed on freshly filtered polycrystalline samples (18.06 mg for 1a and 10.08 mg for 1b) introduced in a polyethylene bag (3 × 0.5 × 0.02 cm) using a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMSXL). The corresponding irradiated compounds were prepared under air at room temperature using a light emitting diode (LED) operating at 365 nm. Surface reflectivity measurements were performed on a home-built system at different temperatures ranging from 10 to 300 K. This setup collects the light reflected by the sample (sum of direct and diffuse reflected light) that is analyzed by a high-sensitivity Hamamatsu 10083CA spectrometer. The spectra are compared to a white reference obtained with a NIST traceable standard for reflectance (SphereOptics, ref SG3054). The background, collected with the light source switched off, is subtracted from all measurements. The reflectivity can be plotted as a function of temperature, time, or wavelength. Different light emitting diodes (LEDs) operating between 365 and 1050 nm and bought from Thorlabs were used for excitation measurements. The temperature dependence of the optical reflectivity spectra was followed during a cycle of cooling–heating with a rate maintained at 4 K·min–1. The excitation/de-excitation experiments were performed between 290 and 295 K.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

The elemental analysis was performed with a PerkinElmer Series II CHNS/O analyzer 2400, at the Servei de Microanàlisi of CSIC, Barcelona, Spain. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellet samples on a Nicolet 5700 FTIR spectrometer. Raman spectra of microcrystalline samples were obtained using a Jobin-Yvon LabRam HR 800 spectrometer with a CCD camera cooled at -70 °C and an optical microscope Olympus BXFM. The Raman spectra of both the open and closed isomers were acquired with an excitation wavelength of 785 nm in order to avoid the cycloreversion reaction of the closed form isomer. The current employed was 185 mA with the minimum power available (10% of the total) to prevent sample damaging. Magnetic measurements were performed on freshly filtered polycrystalline samples (18.06 mg for 1a and 10.08 mg for 1b) introduced in a polyethylene bag (3 × 0.5 × 0.02 cm) using a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMSXL). The corresponding irradiated compounds were prepared under air at room temperature using a light emitting diode (LED) operating at 365 nm. Surface reflectivity measurements were performed on a home-built system at different temperatures ranging from 10 to 300 K. This setup collects the light reflected by the sample (sum of direct and diffuse reflected light) that is analyzed by a high-sensitivity Hamamatsu 10083CA spectrometer. The spectra are compared to a white reference obtained with a NIST traceable standard for reflectance (SphereOptics, ref SG3054). The background, collected with the light source switched off, is subtracted from all measurements. The reflectivity can be plotted as a function of temperature, time, or wavelength. Different light emitting diodes (LEDs) operating between 365 and 1050 nm and bought from Thorlabs were used for excitation measurements. The temperature dependence of the optical reflectivity spectra was followed during a cycle of cooling-heating with a rate maintained at 4 K⋅min-1. The excitation/de-excitation experiments were performed between 290 and 295 K.

elements.content: Data were collected on blue (1a) and green (1b) plates using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker APEX II QUAZAR diffractometer equipped with a microfocus multilayer monochromator at 100 K. Data reduction and absorption corrections were performed with SAINT and SADABS. The structures were solved and refined on F 2 with the SHELXTL suite. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The structures were solved and refined on F 2 with the SHELXTL suite. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The pyridine in the axial position of the copper in complex 1a exhibits positional disorder over two locations, which was refined and established in 0.73/0.27 occupancy ratios. In complex 1b a partial ether molecule is disordered over two positions by symmetry. Hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically on their carrier atoms and refined with a riding model where possible. Data available at the CCDC (1448770 and 1448771 for 1a and 1b respectively).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Data were collected on blue (1a) and green (1b) plates using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker APEX II QUAZAR diffractometer equipped with a microfocus multilayer monochromator at 100 K. Data reduction and absorption corrections were performed with SAINT and SADABS. The structures were solved and refined on F 2 with the SHELXTL suite. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The structures were solved and refined on F 2 with the SHELXTL suite. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The pyridine in the axial position of the copper in complex 1a exhibits positional disorder over two locations, which was refined and established in 0.73/0.27 occupancy ratios. In complex 1b a partial ether molecule is disordered over two positions by symmetry. Hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically on their carrier atoms and refined with a riding model where possible. Data available at the CCDC (1448770 and 1448771 for 1a and 1b respectively).

cln_elements.content: Representation of the polymeric chain of 1a with heteroatoms of the asymmetric unit (and some symmetry equivalent) labeled. The polymeric chain of 1b is very similar (see Figure S2).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of the polymeric chain of 1a with heteroatoms of the asymmetric unit (and some symmetry equivalent) labeled. The polymeric chain of 1b is very similar (see Figure S2).

cln_elements.content: Representation of two stacks of polymeric chains of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom), forming two adjacent sheets and emphasizing the 1D channels (1a) or succession of cavities (1b) parallel to a traversing both lattices. The channels are occupied by ordered molecules of pyridine molecules (1a, shown light green) and the cavities (1b) by disordered ether (light blue) or water (red balls). The color code of the polymer is as in Figure .
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Representation of two stacks of polymeric chains of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom), forming two adjacent sheets and emphasizing the 1D channels (1a) or succession of cavities (1b) parallel to a traversing both lattices. The channels are occupied by ordered molecules of pyridine molecules (1a, shown light green) and the cavities (1b) by disordered ether (light blue) or water (red balls). The color code of the polymer is as in Figure  .

cln_elements.content: Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for H 2 L upon continuous irradiation at 295 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for H  2  L upon continuous irradiation at 295 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.

cln_elements.content: Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for 1a upon continuous irradiation at 290 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for 1a upon continuous irradiation at 290 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.

cln_elements.content: Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for 1b upon continuous irradiation at 295 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Evolution of the absolute reflectivity for 1b upon continuous irradiation at 295 K with (A) 365 nm light (3 mW/cm2) and subsequently (B) 455 nm light (20 mW/cm2). (C) Same data plotted as the time evolution of the absolute reflectivity at 500 nm during the two consecutive irradiations.

cln_elements.content: Hirshfeld surfaces of a [Cu­(L)­(py)3] fragment of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom). The right figures are shown in the transparent mode in order to show the underlying molecular fragments. The red circles indicate the area of interest, corresponding to the atoms that displace the most upon the photisomerization. In this area, the surface is slightly more blue for compound 1a.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Hirshfeld surfaces of a [Cu(L)(py)3] fragment of 1a (top) and 1b (bottom). The right figures are shown in the transparent mode in order to show the underlying molecular fragments. The red circles indicate the area of interest, corresponding to the atoms that displace the most upon the photisomerization. In this area, the surface is slightly more blue for compound 1a.

cln_elements.content: Evolution of the Raman spectra (in the window of interest) of ligand H 2 L and complex 1a, respectively, upon continuous irradiation with UV-light (λ < 425 nm) (left panels) and visible light (λ > 430 nm) (right panels), showing the reversible changes occurring upon photoisomerization.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Evolution of the Raman spectra (in the window of interest) of ligand H  2  L and complex 1a, respectively, upon continuous irradiation with UV-light (λ < 425 nm) (left panels) and visible light (λ > 430 nm) (right panels), showing the reversible changes occurring upon photoisomerization.

metadata.title:
Photochromic Performance of Two Cu(II)-One-Dimensional
Solvatomorphs Controlled by Intermolecular Interactions
